string_table.name: npnxnanbnsnfns00000001001
string_table.string: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
After topping up the grease reservoir, you carry out a visual inspection of the area. During the inspection you identify a potential issue. Grease is leaking from some damaged pipework. You decide to replace the pipework to prevent further grease loss. The first step is to complete a new 4 Whats risk assessment to determine the level of risk and identify appropriate controls.

Click on the forward arrow to continue.

Take another look at the scene to identify the hazards associated with this task, use the slider to view, and click on the hazards for further information.

When you are ready, click on the booklet to start the 4 Whats process.
When you have finished reviewing the scene, click on the 4 Whats booklet to continue the process.

This task requires you to work on the grease system, which is currently live, and replace the damaged pipework. Again It’s a type of task that you’ve completed many times before.

Take a look at the typical hazards section of the booklet and identify potential hazards & risks.

Click on the Typical Hazards section now.

Look at the hazards and click on those that you believe to be applicable for this task. Remember, the list is on two pages, and you can turn pages by clicking the page corners.

Again you can click on the top left icon to review the scene.

When you have selected all the applicable hazards, Click the forward arrow to progress.

You have correctly identified Stored Energy and Hand Tools as hazards associated with this task. You must now complete stage 1 of the 4 Whats process.

Click on “Rate the Risk”.
That’s correct – The hazards that you identified pose a moderate risk due to the pressure contained in the grease system.

That’s Correct. You clearly specified the task and location.

There are no Managing Change aspects to this task so this column will remain blank.

The date and the risk assessment rating must also be recorded before moving onto stage 3. These have been recorded here on your behalf.

Now click on the ‘Assessment Record’ button.
That’s correct. This task is simple.

That’s correct - You are very familiar with this task having completed it many times before.

Now add up the score from each row of the risk matrix and click on the appropriate rating box.

That’s correct. You have identified a risk rating of 4. This means that you are required to complete stages 2 & 3 of the 4 Whats process.

Now click on the Record the Task button to complete stage 2.

Now using the Pre-task checklist, select the appropriate hazards & risks that relate to the task.

When you have selected all of the relevant hazards and risks, click on the forward arrow to progress.

This is the emergency telephone number that you entered in your 4 Whats booklet at the start of the module.

The section below the numbers highlights the emergency protocol that you should follow should an incident occur.

Take a moment to review this information.

When you are ready, click on the Assessment Record button to return to stage 3.

Stage 3 of the 4 Whats process is completed for tasks with a risk rating between 3 and 5.

At this point you must document the hazards and risks and identify appropriate controls to enable safe completion of the task.

At the top of the page you will record key details including, the risk rating, the number in the work party, the date, and the location. Enter the risk rating that you identified at stage 1.
Click on the “Task description/Location” section and select an appropriate task record.

That’s correct. These are all foreseeable hazards and risks associated with the task.

You may record additional hazards at the foot of the page.

Click on the page corner to turn the page and progress to the second part of stage 3.

At this point you must specify if this is a Pre task Risk Assessment or a Managing Change assessment.

This is a Pre-Task Risk Assessment. Select the appropriate box to progress.

The first two Whats have been completed on your behalf, based on the hazards and risks that you identified.

Now you must consider what controls are required to manage those risks.

Click on the controls section to view and select appropriate controls.

That’s correct. Isolation & immobilisation will eliminate pressure in the system and potential operation of the equipment. Gloves will minimise potential hand injuries, eye protection will prevent contamination of eyes and removal of the grease will reduce the risk of trips and slips.

Now you must complete the emergency response section. It is critical that you have a plan should something go wrong.

Click on the Emergency Response button to review the emergency protocol.

The appropriate emergency response is likely to be to seek medical assistance in the first instance, or call the relevant emergency number if it’s a serious incident. You could also contact your supervisor or the job owner.

Click the forward arrow to continue.

Once you have identified appropriate controls, confirm this by printing your name on the assessment. If you are completing the task as part of a work party, the names of all work party members must be recorded.

You have successfully completed a 4 Whats risk assessment for this task.

By answering the 4 Whats you have identified:

•Potential hazards,

•Associated Risks,

•Appropriate controls,

•Actions should something go wrong.

You now have a suitable and sufficient risk assessment that will allow you to complete the task.

Click on the forward arrow to return to the main menu.
Now rate the three risk aspects of the task using the matrix.
